Il Conte che d'entrare avea gran voglio</br>Senza dir altro, alla fonte tornava</br>Trovo Morgana, ch' intorno alla foglia</br>Faceva un ballo, e ballando cantava.</br>Piu leggier non si volge al vento foglia</br>Di cio che quella donna si voltava</br>Guardando ora alla terra, ed ora al fole,</br>Il canto suo dicea queste parole.

"Chi cerca in questo mondo aver tesoro</br>O dillentto, e piacere, onore, e stato,</br>Ponga la mano a questa chioma d'oro</br>Ch'io porto in fronte, e lo faro beato;</br>Ma quando ha in in destro si fatto lavoro,</br>Non cerchi indugio, che'l tempo passato</br>Perduto e tutto, e none ritorna mai</br>Ed io mi volto — e lascio l'huomo in guai."

The Count, whose mind was bent to enter there,</br>In silence turn'd, and sought again the rill.</br>Hard by the throne, he found th' Inchantress fair,</br>Who sweetly sang, and gaily danced still.</br>See but yon leaf, light floating on the wind,</br>So lightly did the graceful fairy bound,</br>Now gazing on the Sun, now on the ground,</br>And in these mystic words, her song disclos'd her mind.

"The man who seeks, on earth, for wordly gain,</br>For joy, for honour, for imperial state,</br>Let his quick grasp, the golden lock obtain</br>Which shades my brow — Then will I make him great.</br>But when this valu'd prize becomes his own,</br>He must not sleep, for time, which flies amain,</br>When past, is lost, and ne'er returns again;</br>Then I, too, turn my back, and leave the wretch to moan."</br>
